Machine Learning and Creativity in Music and Sound

This course offers a comprehensive exploration into the intersection of
artificial intelligence, machine learning, and musical creativity. Over the
course of 13 in-depth sessions, students will engage with a variety of topics
that illuminate the roles AI and machine learning currently play and are poised
to play in the future of music and sound. This course aims to equip students
with a robust understanding of contemporary AI tools, their assemblages and
their applications in music production, while simultaneously fostering critical
thinking about the broader implications of these technologies.

The sessions are designed to sequentially
unfold the historical narrative of AI in music, engage with current
philosophical discourses on technology and art, and provide practical
experiences with state-of-the-art AI tools. Beginning with the nascent stages
of algorithmic composition and traversing through to contemporary breakthroughs
in neural synthesis and text-to-audio, attendees will gain firsthand insights
into AI's transformative impact on the musical domain.

A historical
perspective on the development of AI in music.

Detailed
discussions on the unique properties of AI tools and the conceptual spaces they
inhabit.

The recombinant
methods, schemas and structuralist dynamics present in AI interactions.

The practical
application of AI in composition, mixing, mastering, sound generation and
generative music platforms.

Case studies of contemporary artists
incorporating AI into their practices such as Holly Herndon and Oneohtrix Point
Never.

Critical engagement
with the philosophical and ethical dimensions of AI as a musical tool.

Discussions on the
current and speculative future impacts of AI on music production, distribution,
and consumption.

Special attention is devoted to the idiosyncratic nature of AI tools,
underscoring their ability to develop personalized user models and highlighting
their capacity to traverse and reinterpret musical territories. These tools,
capable of being trained on specific datasets, deftly navigate the latent
spaces of musical materiality, offering a tailored and distinctive approach to
musical materials. The course
cultivates a transconstructive sensibility and inferentialist intuition,
encouraging a willingness to engage with AI not solely in a constructive manner
but also with an openness to adversarial musicking and the unconventional.

Interactivity is a cornerstone of this course,
promoting active dialogue, reflection, and experiential learning. Participants
will not only theoretically dissect AI in music but will also operationalize
their knowledge through practical exercises, culminating in individual research
initiatives and dynamic in-class presentations.

Upon completion, participants will have developed both the knowledge to
critically assess AI tools in music and the practical experience to apply these
technologies creatively.

Participants
will depart with the conceptual acuity to
creatively apply AI tools in music, and they will be inspired to think
independently and critically about the evolving landscape of technology in art.
